name: 2. Description & Preparation
content:
Datasets :

The project uses two datasets:

  1. Insurance Claims Data (JSON format):
  • Contains detailed information about individual claims, including:
  • Claim Number (claim_no)
  • Policy Number (policy_no)
  • Claim Date and Incident Date
  • Claim Amounts categorized by property damage, injury, vehicle damage, and the total amount
  • Driver Information (e.g., age, relationship to insured, license issue date)
  • Incident Details (e.g., number of vehicles involved, type of collision, incident severity, number of witnesses)
  • Suspicious Activity Flag: A binary indicator for potential fraudulent claims
  • Example :

{

  "claim_no": "V01KTFH4X2",

  "policy_no": "8JZKBKJ1JO",

  "claim_date": "2022-01-13",

  "claim_amount": {

    "injury": 3629,

    "property": 1444,

    "total": 6471,

    "vehicle": 6185

  },

  "driver": {

    "age": 53.33,

    "insured_relationship": "Self",

    "license_issue_date": "2024-05-17"

  },

  "incident": {

    "date": "1990-05-26",

    "severity": "Minor",

    "type": "Fire",

    "number_of_vehicles_involved": 4

  },

  "suspicious_activity": true

}


2. Insurance Policies Data (CSV format):

  • Contains details about insurance policies, including:
  • Policy Number (policy_no)
  • Policy Start Date and Policy End Date
  • Premium Amount
  • Vehicle Information (make, model, year)
  • Policyholder Information (e.g., name, address)
  1. This data helps link policies to claims and provides additional context about the policyholder and the insured vehicle.


Data Preprocessing

  • Handling Missing Data: Identify and handle missing values in both datasets to ensure a clean dataset for analysis.
  • Feature Engineering: Create new features such as claim-to-premium ratios, policy tenure, and incident frequency.
  • Data Integration: Perform an inner join on the policy_no field to link claims data with policies dataâ€‹(insurance_claims_data).
